replies.msg:
Rafael Hernández

Piqué acts like he doesn’t give a shit about Barcelona anymore, we can pretend he does, but what he’s demonstrated and said over the past two weeks has been shocking.

Decades watching Barcelona and for the first time I haven't looked forward to matches this season. What this board and Valverde have done… Zero enthusiasm.

The best footballer of all time plays for my club, and I can’t enjoy him for the most part lately. It’s criminal, pure despair as a fan.

Football fans have been made hostage by club owners and directors, and there’s no real system that can bring any accountability to the people running them to the ground. The problem with the age of super clubs isn’t just how the smaller clubs will survive in the long term, but also how the main clubs have become too big to fail.

Thankfully, Bartomeu will be gone soon but his decisions will cost a lot for decades.

I don’t believe there’s a bubble in football that will burst, but systematic failure sinking part of the super clubs into mediocrity for years? We’re witnessing the beginning with Arsenal and Manchester United.

Barcelona could sell Jean-Clair Todibo to Bayer 04 Leverkusen in January. The German side plan to offer 10 million euros for the French centre-back. Barça could agree if a buy-back option is included. [kicker]

Rafael Hernández

Borussia Dortmund's coach Favre is getting sacked and Valverde is only leaving next summer. The difference between them?

MESSI.

The Argentinian was as imperial as ever, making two goals and scoring the second, he led the team perfectly when they needed the most. He's 32 and won't be slowing down anytime soon.

Dembélé got injured and only Messi went to offer him support. I was going to call the rest of the players his teammates, but they’re not a team nor mates. Awful. The Frenchman's time at Barcelona is almost over, doubt he will be there come next summer. All three years wasted under Valverde and he also paid for his indiscipline outside the pitch.

It was possibly the first time in half a year that I have seen Barcelona press an opponent effectively. Dortmund had a conservative, almost coward approach, but the merits were there for all to see. De Jong as excellent, not so much for his midfield companions.

Lenglet and Umtiti worked well together, and showed that Piqué deserves the bench. The full backs were mostly quiet because of Dortmund's setup and how effective the pressing was.

Griezmann looked great after he was subbed on, scored a nicely taken goal but he is still wasted on the wing. The only negative is Valverde gets to survive on the job for another day, but let's overlook this for now...

A bit of commentary on BVB, a team I particularly like to watch! Unmistakably the best team to watch in Europe in the final months of 2018, unforgettable performances at times, and their downfall is a huge disappointment. The signings made last summer were great, but Favre isn't extracting the best of his squad anymore and will be gone, the replacement options are rumored to include Niko Kovac... Please, bring someone better.

Hummels hasn't revolutionized the team like Watzke expected when he signed the German back from Bayern. He's been decent for them this season bar injuries, but tonight he was a disaster, all over the place.
